He was a young man of very inferior abilities, and, as is not unfrequently the case, with abilities but moderately cultivated, his feelings were acute. He had been playfully, but seriously, reproached by his wife for the want of care and attention which he had been apt to show to the wishes and inclinations of his mother; and the very circumstance of this reproach, coming as it did from a woman of her warm affections and lively imagination, had been a powerful motive with him to correct what, on reflection, he believed to be a great fault. He had, moreover, been lately reading the very books which teach young men to be steady, sober, and dutiful; and he had been making resolutions of devoting himself to the discharge of his duty. His uncle's legacy, therefore, though it could not equal his expectations, was yet a very welcome addition to his fortune; and he had no sooner received it, than he resolved to do something for the family into which it had fallen; something which might at once greatly benefit them, and atone for his past neglect. He had been at some trouble in seeking an expedient which might satisfy his own conscience, and at the same time make as little inroad as possible on the fortune of his little boy. He had at length formed a plan which he thought very feasible; it was to educate his cousin Elinor, Marianne, and Margaret, at a good school in London, and to pay the expenses of their maintenance himself. This plan he mentioned to his wife, adding, with an air of great generosity, that he should also give them each a thousand pounds on coming of age. Mrs. John Dashwood, though she felt her heart more disposed to generosity of sentiment than of money, was quite ready to join in any measure for the advantage of her mother-in-law's children; and she listened to his proposal with a degree of cordiality which gratified him extremely. They talked the matter over together; they considered it in every light; and the more they deliberated, the more their resolution was confirmed. At length it was determined, and Mr. Dashwood, after writing down a promise to his mother-in-law of five thousand pounds, sent off a servant immediately to Norland, with orders that it should be paid over to Mrs. Dashwood, as soon as she had settled herself in her new home.

Mrs. Dashwood, who had been looking forward to such an introduction with great pleasure, willingly accompanied her new friend; and as they entered the room, the two ladies to whom she was to be presented advanced very kindly to receive her. Mrs. Palmer was a well-looking woman of about thirty, and her air and manner seemed to show a dependence on her own good opinion, and a wish for the same in others. Her complexion was almost too fair to be becoming; but her features were good, and her figure correct. She was dressed in a gown of a bright yellow colour, which, though not new, was extremely neat; and her hair, which wanted but one shade of being red, was carefully dressed and curled, and decorated with a large front comb of gold. Her daughter, who was a very pretty girl of seventeen, had more the air of a simple, unaffected country maiden; her hair was of a light brown, and braided in the same manner as her mother's, but without any ornament. She had a pair of fine, large blue eyes, and her skin was fresh and blooming. She was taller than her mother, and, from the freedom of her air and manner, seemed to be the more the young woman of the two. Mrs. Palmer received Mrs. Dashwood with a very polite, though not a very cordial countenance, and her daughter looked at her with a steady and curious gaze. "My dear Mrs. Jennings," said she, "you have brought us a very great treat. Pray be seated. We are all attention to you." Mrs. Dashwood was as well received by them as her friend could have wished, and they talked together for some time, with great apparent satisfaction on both sides. The conversation turned chiefly on the advantages of the country and the pleasures of a ball-room; and Lucy, the daughter, was called upon to give an account of the last country dance she had been at, which she did with a readiness and animation that proved her to be no novice in the art of dancing or description. Mrs. Dashwood was pleased with her, and amused by her; and the whole time of their being together passed so agreeably to herself, that when she returned to the other drawing-room, she felt as if her visit to London had been already in some measure a source of amusement and entertainment.
